body.p:
In making my bow to you through the
medium of Miss DeCordova, the Bearer of this letter, I beg you
not to bear hand upon me for not visiting since my residence
here, having had enough to occupy both my time and attention
in establishing a school as a means of support, in which I
have been (I E) tolerably successful. No doubt you expected
to hear from me via New Orleans, but setting aside my dislike of
the climate of that place, and the repugnance of my wife to being
again separated from her family, there are other reasons which
I may confide to you, as a fellow labourer in the vineyard of
the Lord, though to an Hebrew I would not reveal them. They
are simply these. Having failed, despite my utmost efforts, in
giving satisfaction to two congregations, Kingston & St. Thomas,
and, instead of kind treatment, having been exposed to insult
by both, I dread the idea of incurring it a third time; and
therefore prefer the toilsome and humble situation of a teacher
to the dignified one of a Jewish minister. Perhaps my own
temper and disposition are to blame; but, if so, is it not preferable
to retire into private life and live in peace, than have them again
excited by the disagreeabilities of a Jewish Congregation?
In St. Thomas, I even offered to serve them gratuitously, as
salary was the bone of contention among the members, provided
they would be at peace with each other. This, the party in power
would not suffer; and subsequently I accepted a very trifling

salary, which was generally 3 quarters in amount, and was content
to receive it in any manner, taking whatever was offered me, which was
not unfrequently 20 dollars at a time! But it was useless. An
angel from Heaven would not satisfy them, and I, who possess
no angelic quality of course found it beyond my capability. To
enumerate the indignities I suffered would fill a volume; and
I endured them patiently till threatened with personal violence.
It was time to resign; and as St. Thomas presented less advantages
than Kingston, behold me here again, welcomed with an intensity
of feeling I was unprepared for, and what is more, with expressions
of profound regret that I ever left. My impression always was,
that neither by preparatory study nor habits, inclination, or temper
was I ever intended or capacitated to minister before the
Lord; circumstances forced the situation on me; and now,
having, without the needful qualifications, gained a reputation
I am unwilling to damage it by continuing in a profession
where there are so many candidates better adapted to supply
vacancies than myself. I am not ignorant that the Congregation
in N. O. give me the preference to any other; this is flattering to my
feelings, an unction to my vanity if you like, but for my own
part, the course I have pursued in declining the appointment,
must, after this candid avowal, be deemed satisfactory by you.
I have now unbosomed myself, and shall be glad to hear
your opinion, as I always set the highest value, on whatever
emanated from you.

I need not say how delighted I shall
be to hear from Miss DeCordova her estimate of my obt friend

Leeser. You will find her a young person of fine mind,
great strength of character, intelligent and feeling. I beg you
will, in concert with all my good friends in Philadelphia,
endeavour to render her stay, which is likely to be of some
continuance, as agreeable as possible. She is exceedingly
dear to every member of our family, and the attention shown
her will be valued as if it were paid to ourselves. I
have prepared her to be pleased with you and your conversation
and being persuaded that you have lost none of your
powers of amusing and instructing, she expects to glean much
information, and derive great pleasure from your society.

There are some small pecuniary matters to
be settled between us, which would have been arranged
ere I quitted St. Thomas, had your agent there Mr. M B
Simmonds furnished me with the accot. in time. I will
see to it and shortly forward you the amot.

Enough for this time, so with prayers
to the searcher of Hearts that your entreaties on behalf
of yourself and Congregation may be heard and favourably
received, and that you may all be inscribed in His eternal
registers for long life, salvation, and pardon; and with the
best wishes of Mrs. N. and myself to you and all friends
